thread.title: Valley Fiesta 2015: Grey skies no deterrent to huge crowds
thread.title_full: Valley Fiesta 2015: Grey skies no deterrent to huge crowds

author: Cameron Atfield
title: Valley Fiesta 2015: Grey skies no deterrent to huge crowds
text:
The calm before the crowds: Georgia Schuller at the Valley Fiesta busker auditions early Saturday morning. Photo: Michelle Smith 
Not even the grey skies could scare thousands off the Valley Fiesta on Saturday afternoon, with the volume and tempo only rising as the sun fell.
Brisbane's biggest annual free music festival, which kicked off on Friday, was expected to attract about 60,000 to the streets and lanes of Fortitude Valley across the weekend.
Organiser Murray Sutherland said, as of 5pm on Saturday, crowds had already exceeded his expectations.
Live street art at The Flying Cock, part of the 2015 Valley Fiesta. Photo: Michelle Smith 
Sutherland said his "guestimate" was about 20,000 had gone through on Saturday, even before the night-time peak.
Advertisement "It's absolutely packed in the main street, it's huge already," he said.
"I'm a bit surprised, because I thought it might be a little bit slow, especially with the wet weather, but Brunswick Street – where the road closure is – is absolutely chockers.
"Brunswick Street Mall has been as well."
Saturday night saw Resin Dogs, Asta, Gypsie & The Cat, Kilter and Alpine, among others, take to the Valley stages.
Sunday will see the QMusic showcase in the Brunswick Street Mall
"That's going to be showcasing the band and the song of the year, from Halfway," Sutherland said.
"So there's nine artists, a full activation there, and there'll be all sorts of snippets of activity through the malls right through Sunday."
Sutherland said it was a massive endeavour to deliver the Valley Fiesta.
"We work closely with Brisbane City Council, the main funder of the event, but it's five months of details planning with the bands, the infrastructure, and all the components to get it to work," he said.
